thread.title: Ryan Seacrest to Produce 'Squad Goals,' a Reality Show That Follows a Group of 20-Somethings From College
thread.title_full: Ryan Seacrest to Produce 'Squad Goals,' a Reality Show That Follows a Group of 20-Somethings From College

title: Ryan Seacrest to Produce 'Squad Goals,' a Reality Show That Follows a Group of 20-Somethings From College
text:
Ryan Seacrest to Produce 'Squad Goals,' a Reality Show That Follows a Group of 20-Somethings From College Comment 0 Subscribe to Newsletter! 
Ryan Seacrest is set to start a new project involving scripted network comedy. The host will executive produce the hybrid sitcom “Squad Goals.” 
Variety exclusively revealed that “Squad Goals” is currently in development at CBS. The comedy show will focus on a group of friends who met in college and are in their late 20s at present. They realize that it is finally time to grow up. Like Us on Facebook 
The script for “Squad Goals” was written by Lindsey Rosin and Aaron Karo, who will also be co-executive producers of the comedy. Although Rosin and Karo has previously worked together, it will be the first time that they collaborate for a major network. Nina Wass of Ryan Seacrest Productions will also serve as executive producer. 
According to sources, the show was loosely inspired by the writers’ own observations on their own lives and friends. Many young adults their age were at a crucial part of their lives and dealing with factors like marriage, mortgages, career and social life. 
Variety wrote that “Squad Goals” is actually an inspiration term that was popularized by Taylor Swift, describing the desire to join the ultimate group of friends. The show is under an overall deal at CBS and will be brought by Ryan Seacrest Productions and CBS Television Studios. 
The Wrap reported that CBS also recently purchased two dramasfrom Seacrest Productions. One is called “The Down Beat,” a drama series written by Paul Downs Colaizzo. The entry focuses on an Atlanta marching band. Billboard wrote that “The Down Beat” is an inspiring story about an ex-business mogul who is on the road for personal retribution by attempting to bring down two warring gangs in Atlanta. The main character offers potential teenage recruits unexpected refuge in the form of a high school marching band. Rapper Chris “Ludacris” Bridges is set to executive produce the show. CBS also assigned showrunner Greg Berlanti to work on a couple of pilots. Berlanti previously worked on CW shows like “Flash,”“Arrow,” and “Supergirl.” It appears that CBS is planning to bring in fresh talent with the presence of Colaizzo, Rosin and Karo. 
The second drama is still untitled but revolves around a cop that tries to rebuild his personal life in Pittsburgh after a devastating scandal. Colaizzo will serve as writer and executive producer of the show, together with Sarah Timberman and Carl Beverly. 
More updates on Ryan Seacrest’s projects are expected soon. Contribute to this Story:
